tonnage|DWT]]--> | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|506|ft|0|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|60|ft|3|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship height = <!--{{convert|xx|ft|x|in|m|2|abbr=on}--> | Ship draught = {{convert|26|ft|3|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship depth = {{convert|39|ft|5|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship range = | Ship power 4-in or 4.7 in gun, 1 x Bofors gun, 4 x machine guns, 1 x kite (''Talthybius'', WWII) }} |}
'''''Talthybius''''' was a {{GRT|10,224}} [[Cargo liner]] that was built in 1911 by [[Scotts Shipbuilding and Engineering Company|Scotts Shipbuilding & Engineering Co Ltd]], [[Greenock]], [[Renfrewshire]], United Kingdom for a British shipping line. She was sunk at [[Singapore]] in an air raid in 1942. Salvaged by the Japanese, she was renamed '''''Taruyasu Maru''''', serving with the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] until 1945 when she either struck a [[naval mine|mine]] off [[Sado Island]] and sank or was sunk in an attack by aircraft of [[Task Force 38]]. She was salvaged by the British, passed to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) and renamed '''''Empire Evenlode'''''. She served until 1949, when she was scrapped.
==Description== The ship was built in 1911 by [[Scotts Shipbuilding and Engineering Company|Scotts Shipbuilding & Engineering Co Ltd]], [[Greenock]], [[Renfrewshire]]. She was yard number 436.<ref name=Clydesite>{{cite web |url=http://www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=19092 |title=Launched 1911: ss TALTHYBIUS |publisher=Clydesite |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
The ship was {{convert|506|ft|0|in|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|60|ft|3|in|m|2}}. She had a depth of {{convert|39|ft|5|in|m|2}}, and a draught of {{convert|22|ft|3|in|m|2}}. She was assessed at {{GRT|10,224}}, {{NRT|6,514}}<!--, x,xxx [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]]-->.<ref name=Talthybius30>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b1165.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
The ship was propelled by a 586 [[nominal horsepower|nhp]] six-cylinder [[triple expansion steam engine]], which had three pairs of cylinders of {{convert|28|in|cm}} inches, {{convert|38+1/2|in|cm}} and {{convert|65|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|48|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by Scotts and drove twin screw [[propeller (ship)|propellers]].<ref name=Talthybius30/> It could propel the ship at a speed of {{convert|12|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=OS9/>
==History== ''Talthybius'' was launched on 7 November 1911,<ref name=Clydesite/> and completed in 1912.<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref> The United Kingdom Official Number 131411 and [[Code Letters]] HVDQ were allocated. Her port of registry was [[Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]].<ref name=Talthybius30/> She was built to serve on the United Kingdom – Australia route.<ref name=SFPAMA091211>{{cite news |title=untitled |newspaper=Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser |date=9 December 1911 |page=2 |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb19111209.2.6.aspx }}</ref> She was completed in February 1912, leaving Liverpool on her [[maiden voyage]] on 4 February, bound for [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada.<ref name=SFC050212>{{cite news |title=Shipping Intelligence |newspaper=San Francisco Call |date=5 February 1912 |page=11 |url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cdnc/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&cl=search&d=SFC19120205.2.110.7&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-IN-Talthybius+----# }}</ref> In November 1914, ''Talthybius'' was engaged in transporting 1,000 Chinese from the United States to [[Hong Kong]] to spend Christmas there with their families.<ref name=TST19114>{{cite news |title=untitled |newspaper=The Straits Times |issue=19 November 1914 |page=8 |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19141119.2.38.aspx }}</ref> On arrival at [[Kobe]], Japan on 23 July 1925, 62 Chinese crew deserted the ship.<ref name=Times240725>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Chinese Crew Deserts |day_of_week=Friday |date=24 July 1925 |page_number=16 |issue=44022 |column=E }}</ref> At 03:00 (local time) on 23 August 1925, ''Talthybius'' was in collision with the Chinese fishing [[junk (ship)|junk]] ''1605'' off [[Waglan Island]], Hong Kong. ''1605'' was sunk; a Court of Inquiry found that she was not showing any lights and ''Talthybius'' was cleared of any blame for the collision.<ref name=SFPMA221025>{{cite news |title=Hongkong Court of Inquiry |newspaper=Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser |date=22 October 1955 |page=12 |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb19251022.2.86.aspx }}</ref>
From 1934, ''Talthybius'' was recorded as holding a passenger certificate.<ref name=Cargoliner>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/ship.php?ship_id=35779&name=Talthybius |title=Details of the Ship |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She was then assessed as {{GRT|10254|link=off}}, {{NRT|6,492|link=off}}. With the changes to Code Letters in 1934, ''Talthybius'' was allocated the letters GPZN.<ref name=Talthybius37>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0854.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> For a couple of years in the 1930s, ''Talthybius'' was used as an accommodation ship at [[Birkenhead]], [[Cheshire]].<ref name=Stanworth>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ww2peopleswar/stories/00/a6021000.shtml |first=Rob |last=Stanworth |title=J W Stanworth - Memoirs part 1 |publisher=BBC People's War |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
On April 11, 1939, ''Talthybius'' suffered an explosion in one of her coal bunkers which blew off two hatches and injured four [[Stoker (occupation)|firemen]]. She anchored in the Royal Roads off [[San Francisco, California]], United States, for inspection. She was allowed to continue her voyage from [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada to [[Hong Kong]].<ref name=Times130439>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Casualty Reports |day_of_week=Thursday |date=13 April 1939 |page_number=22 |issue=48278 |column=F }}</ref> In 1939, and again in 1940, ''Talthybius'' carried [[gold bullion]] worth [[Pound Sterling|£1,000,000]] from [[Hong Kong]] to Canada.<ref name=Pingwo>{{cite web |url=http://www.navyhistory.org.au/ping-wos-golden-secret/ |title=Ping Wo’s Golden Secret |first=James |last=Eagles |publisher=Naval Historical Society of Australia |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> ''Talthybius'' was a member of Convoy HX 102, which departed from [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], Canada on 11 January 1941 and arrived at Liverpool on 29 January. She was carrying general and special cargo.<ref name=HX102>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx102.html |title=CONVOY HX 102 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She was a member of Convoy OB 297, which departed from Liverpool on 12 March and dispersed at sea on 17 March. ''Talthybius'' was bound for Halifax and [[Saint John, New Brunswick]] with general cargo.<ref name=OB297>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ob/index.html?ob297.htm~obmain |title=Convoy OB.297 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She was due to return with Convoy HX 119, but did not join that convoy.<ref name=HX119>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx119.html |title=CONVOY HX 119A & HX 119B |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> ''Talthybius'' joined Convoy HX 120, which departed from Halifax on 10 April and arrived at Liverpool on 29 April. She was carrying general cargo and {{convert|500|LT|kg}} of [[trinitrotoluene|TNT]].<ref name=HX120>{{cite web|url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx120.html |title=CONVOY HX 120 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> On 4 May, ''Talthybius'' was damaged in an air raid on Liverpool. She suffered further damage in another raid four days later.<ref name=NH044122>{{cite web |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xDKWW2-4104-31APR02.htm |title=NAVAL EVENTS, APRIL 1941, Part 2 of 2, Tuesday 15th – Wednesday 30th |publisher=Naval History |accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
''Talthybius'' was a member of Convoy OB 330, which departed from Liverpool on 2 June and dispersed at sea on 7 June. She was bound for [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada.<ref name=OB330>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ob2/index.html?ob.php?convoy=330!~obmain |title=Convoy OB.330 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She returned with Convoy HX 136, which departed from Halifax on 30 June and arrived at Liverpool on 18 July. ''Talthybius'' was carrying general cargo and [[shell (projectile)|shells]]. She also carried the [[Convoy Commodore]], who described the ship as "efficient and well manned" with "a good fighting spirit". She was only able to fly a [[kite]] when the wind was from the starboard due to only having one fitting for kites. The commodore recommended that she be equipped to fly kites from both sampson posts.<ref name=HX136>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx136.html |title=CONVOY HX 136 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
''Talthybius'' was a member of Convoy ON 3, which departed from Liverpool on 31 July and dispersed at sea on 14 August. She was carrying a number of passengers bound for Montreal.<ref name=ON3>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=3!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.3 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She returned with Convoy HX 148, which departed from Halifax on 4 September and arrived at Liverpool on 17 September. ''Talthybius'' was carrying general cargo.<ref name=HX148>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx148.html |title=CONVOY HX 148 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
''Talthybius'' then sailed to [[Holyhead]], [[Anglesey]], from where she departed on 30 September to join Convoy BB 82,<ref name=Port>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/ports/index.html?search.php?vessel=TALTHYBIUS~armain |title=TALTHYBIUS |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> which had departed from the [[Belfast Lough]] on that day and arrived at [[Milford Haven]], [[Pembrokeshire]] on 1 October.<ref name=BB82>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/bb/index.html?bb.php?convoy=82!~bbmain |title=Convoy BB.82 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She then sailed on to [[Cardiff]], [[Glamorgan]], arriving the next day. She returned to Milford Haven, from where she departed on 12 October to join Convoy OS 9,<ref name=Port/> which sailed from Liverpool on 13 October and arrived at [[Freetown]], Sierra Leone on 1 November. ''Talthybius'' was carrying general cargo bound for [[Alexandria]], Egypt. She was armed with a 4-inch or 4.7-inch gun, a [[Bofors gun]], four machine guns and a kite.<ref name=OS9>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/oskms/index.html?os009.htm~osmain |title=Convoy OS.9 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref>
''Talthybius'' was a member of Convoy BM 10, which departed from [[Bombay]], [[British India|India]] on 8 January 1942 and arrived at [[Singapore]] on 25 January. She was carrying a cargo described as "stores",<ref name=BM10>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/bm/index.html?bm.php?convoy=10!~bmmain |title=Convoy BM.10 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> which included [[lorry|lorries]] and [[tank]]s. On 3 February 1942, two direct hits were scored on ''Talthybius'' during a Japanese air raid on [[Singapore]] and she was set on fire. She was declared to be unseaworthy and abandoned, sinking in the Empire Dock, to where she had been moved following the raid.<ref name=Cofepow>{{cite web |url=http://www.cofepow.org.uk/pages/ships_list.html |title=LIST OF SHIPS INVOLVED IN SE ASIA |publisher=COFEPOW |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> The officers and European crew from ''Talthybius'' formed part of the crew of {{HMAS|Ping Wo}}, which took 600 refugees form Singapore to [[Java]], Indonesia and then towed {{HMAS|Vendetta|D69|6}} from [[Tanjung Priok]], Indonesia to [[Fremantle]], Australia. The Chinese crewmembers decided to take their chances in Singapore.<ref name=Pingwo/>
''Talthybius'' was salvaged by the Japanese, repaired and returned to service as ''Taruyasu Maru'',<ref name=Ships/> operated by the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]].<ref name=NEI>{{cite web |url=http://www.dutcheastindies.webs.com/allied_losses.html |title=Allied Merchant Ship Losses in the Pacific and Southeast Asia (December 7th, 1941 - March 9th, 1942) |publisher=L Klemen |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> The fate of ''Taruyasu Maru'' is unclear, as conflicting accounts state that either she struck a [[naval mine|mine]] off [[Sado Island]], Japan ({{coord|37|07|N|137|04|E}}}) and sank 30 June 1945,<ref name=Mariners>{{cite web |url=http://www.mariners-l.co.uk/EmpireD.html |title=EMPIRE - D - E |publisher=Mariners |accessdate=96 September 2011}}</ref> or she was sunk by [[United States Navy]] aircraft from [[Task Force 38]] in [[Maizuru Bay]], Japan on 30 July 1945.<ref name=Cofepow/><ref name=Takane>{{cite web |url=http://www.combinedfleet.com/Takane_t.htm |title=IJN Escort Takane: Tabular Record of Movement |first1=Bob |last1=Hackett |first2=Peter |last2=Cundall |year=2009 |publisher=Combined Fleet |accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> She was salvaged by the British and repaired. Passed to the MoWT, she was renamed ''Empire Evenlode''.<ref name=Ships/> She was again placed under the management of A Holt & Co Ltd.<ref name=Clydesite/> On 1 December 1945, she started the voyage back to the United Kingdom. This took until 8 May 1946 to complete due to the poor condition of the ship. ''Empire Evenlode'' served until 1949, when she was scrapped at [[Briton Ferry]], Glamorgan.<ref name=Ships/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/ships/1912/TALTHYBIUS_436.jpg Photo of ''Talthybius''] *[http://greatsoutherncards.com.au/images/empire-evenlode-phc.jpg Photo of ''Empire Evenlode'']
